htmlEmbed:
U.S. emissions linked to over $1.8 trillion of global economic losses, study saysSteven Mufson6/12/2022

The report found just five of the world’s leading emitters of greenhouse gases caused $6 trillion in global economic losses through warming caused by their emissions from 1990 to 2014.

Climate & EnvironmentArchivedRead

class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The United States and China, the world’s two leading greenhouse gas emitters, are each responsible for more than $1.8 trillion of global income losses from 1990 to 2014, according to a new study that links the emissions in individual countries to the economic impacts of climate change in others. The report may bolster the scientific basis for legal claims for losses tied to global warming.</p></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class=" b bh bc-gray-lighter mb-md hide-for-print" data-qa="subscribe-promo"><a class="pt-sm pb-sm flex items-center bold font-xxxs font-xxs-ns offblack hover-blue-bright justify-between" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/02/22/climate-change-actions-carbon-footprint/?itid=lk_cta_ssinline" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" style="border:none"><span class="mr-xs flex items-center"><span class="ml-xs">10 steps you can take to lower your carbon footprint</span></span><svg class="content-box" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 16 16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" style="transition:right .2s;position:relative;right:4px;fill:#666" aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" role="img"><title>ArrowRight</title><path d="M7.664 1.25l6 6a1 1 0 010 1.414l-6 6L6.25 13.25 10.499 9H2V7h8.585L6.25 2.664 7.664 1.25z" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></a></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The Dartmouth College <a href="https://home.dartmouth.edu/news/2022/07/study-shows-economic-impacts-greenhouse-gas-emissions" target=_blank>study</a>, published in the journal Climatic Change, linked one nation’s emissions of heat-trapping gases to losses and gains in the gross domestic product of 143 countries for which data is available. It found that five of the world’s leading emitters of greenhouse gases caused $6 trillion of global economic losses through warming caused by their emissions from 1990 to 2014. Economic losses caused by Russia, India and Brazil exceeds $500 billion over that period for each of those three emitter countries.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“This research provides an answer to the question of whether there is a scientific basis for climate liability claims. The answer is yes,” said Christopher Callahan, a doctoral candidate at Dartmouth and an author of the study, in a statement. “We have quantified each nation’s culpability for historical temperature-driven income changes in every other country.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The United States, for example, inflicted $34 billion of economic losses on the Philippines during the 1990 to 2014 period, considering emissions generated from U.S. territory.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The researchers said that U.S. emissions produced a 0.054-degree Celsius change in the global average temperatures in that period. This resulted in a 0.04-degree Celsius change in the average temperature in Indonesia over the same period, a change attributable only to emissions from the United States.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“This change may seem small, but because Indonesia is a warm, tropical country, increases in temperature are quite harmful to its economy,” Callahan said. “Every 1-degree increase in its local temperature reduces its economic growth by 1.6 percentage points.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Putting these numbers together showed the United States reduced Indonesia’s economic growth by 0.065 percentage points each year in that same period. And, Callahan said, because Indonesia is a populous country with a large economy, even these small reductions in economic growth added up to large absolute number: a loss of $124 billion over the period.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The question of liability for climate change has been the subject of a growing number of lawsuits worldwide.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Cities and states have sued the global oil company ExxonMobil for not disclosing to investors the risks of climate damage. A variety of environmental groups took Shell to court in the Netherlands. And a Peruvian farmer is suing RWE, alleging that Germany’s largest utility, which scientists say has emitted 0.47 percent of the cumulative global industrial emissions of carbon and methane between 1751 and 2010, should have to pay its share to protect a small town in the Peruvian mountains.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Meanwhile, many developing countries have sought to get industrialized nations to pay for “loss and damages” they link to decades of emissions.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“For the first time, we have been able to show clear and statistically significant linkages between the emissions of specific countries and historical economic losses experienced by other countries,” Callahan said. “This is about the culpability of one country to another country, not the effect of overall global warming on a country.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">White House climate envoy John F. Kerry said at the close of the Glasgow climate summit that he understood the push for loss and damage payments but that there was no spending mechanism.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The Dartmouth team believes its study “discredits the idea that climate mitigation is simply a ‘collective action problem,’ where no one country acting alone can have an effect on the impacts of global warming,” said Justin Mankin, an assistant professor of geography at Dartmouth and senior researcher on the study.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Other studies have relied on one or two parts of the three-step approach taken by the Dartmouth team.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“Scientists have previously described the historical economic effects of global warming, showing that climate change has benefited cooler, well-off countries and harmed warmer, less-well-off countries,” Callahan said. But, he said, they have not quantified the culpability of individual emitters. Another recent study quantified the effects that individual countries’ emissions can have on other countries’ temperatures but did not quantify the economic effects of these temperature changes.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“Our work can be seen as uniting these two disparate strains of work in a single integrated framework,” he said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/#/bundle/energy?method=SURL&location=ART&itid=lk_interstitial_manual_26">Sign up for the latest news about climate change, energy and the environment, delivered every Thursday</a></span></p></div><div class="mb-lg-mod hide-for-print" id="link-box"><div data-qa="content" class="linkbox-content"><h3 class="font-md font-bold font--headline offblack lh-md pb-xs" data-qa="linkbox-headline">More on climate change</h3><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Understanding our climate: </b><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2019/national/climate-environment/thermometers-climate-change/?itid=lb_more-on-climate-change_1" target=_blank>Global warming is a real phenomenon</a>, and weather disasters are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2020/10/22/climate-curious-disasters-climate-change/" target=_blank>undeniably linked to it</a>. As temperatures rise, heat waves are more often sweeping the globe — and parts of the world are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/interactive/2021/climate-change-humidity/?itid=lb_more-on-climate-change_4" target=_blank>becoming too hot to survive</a>.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>What can be done? </b>The Post is tracking a variety of <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/" target=_blank>climate solutions</a>, as well as the Biden administration’s <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2021/climate-environment/biden-climate-environment-actions/?itid=lb_more-on-climate-change_9" target=_blank>actions on environmental issues</a>. It can feel overwhelming facing the impacts of climate change, but there are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/wellness/climate-change-anxiety-dread-cope/2021/07/14/471eb264-e4d4-11eb-b722-89ea0dde7771_story.html" target=_blank>ways to cope with climate anxiety</a>.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Inventive solutions: </b>Some people have built <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/01/04/earthship-houses-climate-change/" target=_blank>off-the-grid homes from trash</a> to stand up to a changing climate. As seas rise, others are exploring <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/interactive/2021/cop26-scotland-wave-energy-renewables/?itid=lb_more-on-climate-change_14" target=_blank>how to harness marine energy</a>.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Have a question about climate change or climate solutions? </b><a href="https://hosted-washpost.submissionplatform.com/sub/hosted/60dcea87da73bf002f659123">Share it with us.</a> You can also <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/energy-and-environment/">sign up for our newsletter on climate change, energy and environment</a>.</p></div><div class="flex justify-center (Drew Angerer/Getty Images)","distributor":{"category":"wires"},"height":3787,"subtype":"WireImage","taxonomy":{},"type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/26IY7VAB6EI63C7LFNHEQGYVAA.jpg","width":5680,"originalIdx":0},{"_id":"4XA4KV2ZANF5HCGXWRPQQNBSZE","additional_properties":{},"content":"The United States and China, the world’s two leading greenhouse gas emitters, are each responsible for more than $1.8 trillion of global income losses from 1990 to 2014, according to a new study that links the emissions in individual countries to the economic impacts of climate change in others. The report may bolster the scientific basis for legal claims for losses tied to global warming.","type":"text","originalIdx":1},{"_id":"3R4JVJITNBFPDL75D7A5WKCTFQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"The Dartmouth College \u003ca href=\"https://home.dartmouth.edu/news/2022/07/study-shows-economic-impacts-greenhouse-gas-emissions\" target=_blank\u003estudy\u003c/a\u003e, published in the journal Climatic Change, linked one nation’s emissions of heat-trapping gases to losses and gains in the gross domestic product of 143 countries for which data is available. It found that five of the world’s leading emitters of greenhouse gases caused $6 trillion of global economic losses through warming caused by their emissions from 1990 to 2014. Economic losses caused by Russia, India and Brazil exceeds $500 billion over that period for each of those three emitter countries.","type":"text","originalIdx":2},{"_id":"H45B7VIJGJEMDBAKAUNRNVZ6VM","additional_properties":{},"content":"“This research provides an answer to the question of whether there is a scientific basis for climate liability claims. The answer is yes,” said Christopher Callahan, a doctoral candidate at Dartmouth and an author of the study, in a statement. “We have quantified each nation’s culpability for historical temperature-driven income changes in every other country.”","type":"text","originalIdx":3},{"_id":"ZPJ75KW65NATBDUJOBAE6KCJKI","additional_properties":{},"content":"The United States, for example, inflicted $34 billion of economic losses on the Philippines during the 1990 to 2014 period, considering emissions generated from U.S. territory.","type":"text","originalIdx":4},{"_id":"HHGGDE2V3FAODC4ZMXYZAFGJJA","additional_properties":{},"content":"The researchers said that U.S. emissions produced a 0.054-degree Celsius change in the global average temperatures in that period. This resulted in a 0.04-degree Celsius change in the average temperature in Indonesia over the same period, a change attributable only to emissions from the United States.","type":"text","originalIdx":5},{"_id":"CYIU2TZ3DFCG3DAARYYV6TAYXE","additional_properties":{},"content":"“This change may seem small, but because Indonesia is a warm, tropical country, increases in temperature are quite harmful to its economy,” Callahan said. “Every 1-degree increase in its local temperature reduces its economic growth by 1.6 percentage points.”","type":"text","originalIdx":6},{"_id":"CEQRNESZINBHXLBRW5YRZ2FIXQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Putting these numbers together showed the United States reduced Indonesia’s economic growth by 0.065 percentage points each year in that same period. And, Callahan said, because Indonesia is a populous country with a large economy, even these small reductions in economic growth added up to large absolute number: a loss of $124 billion over the period.","type":"text","originalIdx":7},{"_id":"PXHHLXN4YZEG7AACKCAMJPF3Z4","additional_properties":{},"content":"The question of liability for climate change has been the subject of a growing number of lawsuits worldwide.","type":"text","originalIdx":8},{"_id":"HTD5SDJ3Z5AHPNSHXP5MBHCA44","additional_properties":{},"content":"Cities and states have sued the global oil company ExxonMobil for not disclosing to investors the risks of climate damage. A variety of environmental groups took Shell to court in the Netherlands. And a Peruvian farmer is suing RWE, alleging that Germany’s largest utility, which scientists say has emitted 0.47 percent of the cumulative global industrial emissions of carbon and methane between 1751 and 2010, should have to pay its share to protect a small town in the Peruvian mountains.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"AZBT5O7HKJFXHKWXMQUKBODHIA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Meanwhile, many developing countries have sought to get industrialized nations to pay for “loss and damages” they link to decades of emissions.","type":"text","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"6UQYZ4CLWNBGXHCKRNT6TJOR54","additional_properties":{},"content":"“For the first time, we have been able to show clear and statistically significant linkages between the emissions of specific countries and historical economic losses experienced by other countries,” Callahan said. “This is about the culpability of one country to another country, not the effect of overall global warming on a country.”","type":"text","originalIdx":11},{"_id":"OZSQBJQ3ZRBUNGZYXJBV5GTKSI","additional_properties":{},"content":"White House climate envoy John F. Kerry said at the close of the Glasgow climate summit that he understood the push for loss and damage payments but that there was no spending mechanism.","type":"text","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"OYXCE66PYJAGHMFS3N3IBVGSAA","additional_properties":{},"content":"The Dartmouth team believes its study “discredits the idea that climate mitigation is simply a ‘collective action problem,’ where no one country acting alone can have an effect on the impacts of global warming,” said Justin Mankin, an assistant professor of geography at Dartmouth and senior researcher on the study.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"EBHCN6UUYZFRVBNY2O5DZJ5YIY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Other studies have relied on one or two parts of the three-step approach taken by the Dartmouth team.","type":"text","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"H7MZODIQVVB2ZJROE62UIARMTI","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Scientists have previously described the historical economic effects of global warming, showing that climate change has benefited cooler, well-off countries and harmed warmer, less-well-off countries,” Callahan said. But, he said, they have not quantified the culpability of individual emitters. Another recent study quantified the effects that individual countries’ emissions can have on other countries’ temperatures but did not quantify the economic effects of these temperature changes.","type":"text","originalIdx":15},{"_id":"YJDKVHLYUBFADHF2MUSL5XGO7M","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Our work can be seen as uniting these two disparate strains of work in a single integrated framework,” he said.","type":"text","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"RDCREDFFEJBIPMJ52PLEANMHNI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Sign up for the latest news about climate change, energy and the environment, delivered every Thursday","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/#/bundle/energy?method=SURL\u0026location=ART","originalIdx":17}],"content_restrictions":{"content_code":"default"},"credits":{"by":[{"_id":"mufsonsj","additional_properties":{"original":{"_id":"mufsonsj","author_type":"Staff writer","awards":[{"name":"Shared the following: 2020 Pulitzer Prize for explanatory journalism for climate change series \"2C: Beyond the Limit.\" 2011 Sigma Delta Chi award for \"Breakaway Wealth\"; 2012 American Geophysical Union's David Perlman award for explanatory earthquake coverage; 2009 Association of Food Journalists for project; 1988 Alicia Pattterson Foundation fellowship"}],"beat":"The business of climate change","bio":"Steven Mufson covers the business of climate change for The Washington Post. readabilityObject.title: U.S. emissions linked to over $1.8 trillion of global economic losses, study says
readabilityObject.content:
The United States and China, the world’s two leading greenhouse gas emitters, are each responsible for more than $1.8 trillion of global income losses from 1990 to 2014, according to a new study that links the emissions in individual countries to the economic impacts of climate change in others. The report may bolster the scientific basis for legal claims for losses tied to global warming.

The Dartmouth College study, published in the journal Climatic Change, linked one nation’s emissions of heat-trapping gases to losses and gains in the gross domestic product of 143 countries for which data is available. It found that five of the world’s leading emitters of greenhouse gases caused $6 trillion of global economic losses through warming caused by their emissions from 1990 to 2014. Economic losses caused by Russia, India and Brazil exceeds $500 billion over that period for each of those three emitter countries.

“This research provides an answer to the question of whether there is a scientific basis for climate liability claims. The answer is yes,” said Christopher Callahan, a doctoral candidate at Dartmouth and an author of the study, in a statement. “We have quantified each nation’s culpability for historical temperature-driven income changes in every other country.”

The United States, for example, inflicted $34 billion of economic losses on the Philippines during the 1990 to 2014 period, considering emissions generated from U.S. territory.

The researchers said that U.S. emissions produced a 0.054-degree Celsius change in the global average temperatures in that period. This resulted in a 0.04-degree Celsius change in the average temperature in Indonesia over the same period, a change attributable only to emissions from the United States.

“This change may seem small, but because Indonesia is a warm, tropical country, increases in temperature are quite harmful to its economy,” Callahan said. “Every 1-degree increase in its local temperature reduces its economic growth by 1.6 percentage points.”

Putting these numbers together showed the United States reduced Indonesia’s economic growth by 0.065 percentage points each year in that same period. And, Callahan said, because Indonesia is a populous country with a large economy, even these small reductions in economic growth added up to large absolute number: a loss of $124 billion over the period.

The question of liability for climate change has been the subject of a growing number of lawsuits worldwide.

Cities and states have sued the global oil company ExxonMobil for not disclosing to investors the risks of climate damage. A variety of environmental groups took Shell to court in the Netherlands. And a Peruvian farmer is suing RWE, alleging that Germany’s largest utility, which scientists say has emitted 0.47 percent of the cumulative global industrial emissions of carbon and methane between 1751 and 2010, should have to pay its share to protect a small town in the Peruvian mountains.

Meanwhile, many developing countries have sought to get industrialized nations to pay for “loss and damages” they link to decades of emissions.

“For the first time, we have been able to show clear and statistically significant linkages between the emissions of specific countries and historical economic losses experienced by other countries,” Callahan said. “This is about the culpability of one country to another country, not the effect of overall global warming on a country.”

White House climate envoy John F. Kerry said at the close of the Glasgow climate summit that he understood the push for loss and damage payments but that there was no spending mechanism.

The Dartmouth team believes its study “discredits the idea that climate mitigation is simply a ‘collective action problem,’ where no one country acting alone can have an effect on the impacts of global warming,” said Justin Mankin, an assistant professor of geography at Dartmouth and senior researcher on the study.

Other studies have relied on one or two parts of the three-step approach taken by the Dartmouth team.

“Scientists have previously described the historical economic effects of global warming, showing that climate change has benefited cooler, well-off countries and harmed warmer, less-well-off countries,” Callahan said. But, he said, they have not quantified the culpability of individual emitters. Another recent study quantified the effects that individual countries’ emissions can have on other countries’ temperatures but did not quantify the economic effects of these temperature changes.

“Our work can be seen as uniting these two disparate strains of work in a single integrated framework,” he said.
